_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary

EPA Facility # 100000233124

3815 Marion St.

Albany, OR 97308



The Following subsections outline the Executive Summary requirements for EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTIONS AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

SnoTemp located at 3815 Marion St. Albany, Oregon abides by the emergency response procedures detailed in the Emergency Response Plan.  The plan is designed to meet the following objectives:

To save lives

To protect the environment

To minimize property damage



SnoTemp's Emergency Response Team are the designated emergency coordinators.  The Plan provides response organization, ammonia health hazards, evacuation routes and mitigation procedures to respond to emergency situations at the facility.  The Plan is reviewed once a year or as needed to ensure compliance with PSM and RMP regulations or for facility changes.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

SnoTemp maintains thermal environments for human food item storage and integrity of these products.  The system consists of an ammonia refrigeration system which includes compressors, condensers, evaporators, vessels and piping.  Controls consist of a secure computerized system which follows user defined set points and provides text alarms to multiple operators if any preset parameters are breached.  Text alerts start with a warning and if not addressed will go into alarm and shut systems down.  Ammonia the refrigerant, is changed from liquid to vapor as it absorbs heat then changed back to a liquid through pressure increases and heat dissipation.  This process of removes heat from insulated storage rooms and expels the heat outside the system.  Typical operating pressures range from 0 psig to 140 psig across this process.



Anyrdrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) is the refrigerant used in this system.



The total ammonia quantity of this system is above the 10,000 pound threshold quantity for reporting.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SP

ECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The SnoTemp facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:



IIAR Bulletin 107 - "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

IIAR Bulletin 109 - "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

IIAR Bulletin R1 - A guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



In addition, SnoTemp has implemented a Process Safety Management program for compliance with the OSHA 1910.119 regulation.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases of ammonia at this facility over the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Albany SnoTemp facility has an Emergency Response Program in place.  Team members have all had 40 hour or 24 hour HAZWOPER training with annual 8 hour refresher training with third party trainers.  We only respond to levels below 300 ppm.  We have a great capability to respond remotely to alerts and make changes through our refrigeration control system from remote computers or cell phones.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We continue to seek improvements in our training of operators through LITMOS training scheduler.  We just purchased a web based PSM/RMP program to have better insight to our PSM/RMP compliance standing and allow other select people to see our performance, all as a means to be better and safer as an ammonia refrigeration facility.
